member.summary: Indicates whether the puzzle is solved, or failed by . If the property returns , properties and won't be empty.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.IsPearl
member.summary: Indicates whether the puzzle is a pearl puzzle, which means the first step must be an indirect technique usage.
member.returns:
Returns a ? value indicating the result. The values are:
Value Meaning
The puzzle has a unique solution, and the first set step has same difficulty with the whole steps.
The puzzle has a unique solution, but the first set step does not have same difficulty with the whole steps.
The puzzle has multiple solutions, or the puzzle has no valid solution.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.IsDiamond
member.summary: Indicates whether the puzzle is a diamond puzzle, which means the first deletion has the same difficulty with the maximum difficulty of the whole steps.
member.returns:
Returns a ? value indicating the result. The values are:
Value Meaning
The puzzle has a unique solution, and the first deletion step has same difficulty with the whole steps.
The puzzle has a unique solution, but the first deletion step does not have same difficulty with the whole steps.
The puzzle has multiple solutions, or the puzzle has no valid solution.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.MaxDifficulty
member.summary: Indicates the maximum difficulty of the puzzle.
member.remarks: When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the maximum value among all difficulty ratings in solving steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, or else the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be always 200, equal to .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.TotalDifficulty
member.summary: Indicates the total difficulty rating of the puzzle.
member.remarks: When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps recorded in . However, if the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be 0.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.PearlDifficulty
member.summary: Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .
member.remarks: When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first delete step that cause a set.
member.seealso: Concept for EP, ER and ED

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.DiamondDifficulty

summary.para: Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .
When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first delete step.

member.seealso: Concept for EP, ER and ED

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.StepsSpan
member.summary: Returns a of instances, whose internal values come from .

summary.para: Indicates the wrong step found. In general cases, if the property keeps value, it'll mean the puzzle is invalid to solve, or the solver has found one error step to apply, that causes the original puzzle become invalid. In this case we can check this property to get the wrong information to debug the error, or tell the author himself directly, with the inner value of this property held.
However, if the puzzle is successful to be solved, the property won't contain any value, so it'll keep the reference. Therefore, please check the nullability of this property before using.

In general, this table will tell us the nullability of this property:
Nullability Description
Not The puzzle is failed to solve, and the solver has found an invalid step to apply.
Other cases.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.ToString(Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.FormattingOptions,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Returns a string that represents the current object, with the specified formatting options.
member.returns: A string that represents the current object.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.ToString(Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisResult.FormattingOptions,System.IFormatProvider,System.Func{System.String,Sudoku.Analytics.Step,System.String})
member.summary: Returns a string that represents the current object, with the specified formatting options, with a string replacer method that can enhance the output string.
member.param: The string replacer method that can substitute each step string.
member.returns: A string that represents the current object.

remarks.para:
The argument enhances the text output. You can replace it with whatever you want to display. For example, in stream, you can use Epson formatting syntax to output text by using special escaped character '\e':
\e[38;2;255;0;0mRed text\e[0m \e[48;2;0;255;0mGreen background\e[0m \e[38;2;0;0;255;48;2;255;255;0mBlue text with a yellow background\e[0m
Here, you can use statements like \e[38;2;<red>;<green>;<blue>m and \e[0m to control output text color, where:
Value Meaning
38 Foreground
48 Background

Some options may not relate to a real instance directly, but relate to a that a instance can create. For example, setting notation to the coordinates.

member.summary: Indicates whether the step searcher will checks for hidden singles in rows or columns if property has flag .

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Configuration.StepGathererOptions.UseIttoryuMode
member.summary: Indicates whether the searching module will use ittoryu mode to calculate steps.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Configuration.StepGathererOptions.PrimarySingle
member.summary: Indicates the preferred single technique.

remarks.para: If the value isn't , the analyzer will ignore the other single technique not related to this field; in other words, the analyzer module will only perform usages of the specified technique, determining whether the puzzle can be finished by only use this technique.
For example, if the value is , the analyzer will only use naked singles to finish the puzzle. If the puzzle cannot be solved, the analyzer will return an with a value.
Please note that if hidden single flag is chosen , full houses will also be used; this is an only exception.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsWoodsWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is formed a W-Wing.
member.remarks: A valid pattern of W-Wing is (x=y)-y=y-(y=x), symmetric.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsMedusaWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is formed a M-Wing.
member.remarks: A valid pattern of M-Wing is (x=y)-y=(y-x)=x, asymmetric.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsSplitWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is formed a S-Wing.
member.remarks: A valid pattern of S-Wing is x=x-(x=y)-y=y, symmetric.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsLocalWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is formed a L-Wing.
member.remarks: A valid pattern of L-Wing is x=(x-y)=(y-z)=z, asymmetric.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsHybridWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is formed a H-Wing.
member.remarks: A valid pattern of H-Wing is (x=y)-(y=z)-z=z, asymmetric.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsAlmostLockedSetWWing
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is ALS-W-Wing or grouped ALS-W-Wing.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AlternatingInferenceChain.IsImplicitLoop
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain is an implicit loop, which means the start and end nodes are in a same house using a same digit, or just in a same cell with different digits.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AlternatingInferenceChain.WeakStart
member.summary: Indicates whether the chain starts with weak link.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AlternatingInferenceChain.CompareTo(Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AlternatingInferenceChain)
member.summary: Determine which instance is greater.
member.param: The other instance to be compared.
member.remarks:
Order rule:
If is , is greater, return -1.
If is not , checks on length:
If length is not same, return 1 when is longer or -1 when is longer.
Determine whether one of two has "self constraint" (i.e. false -> true confliction).
If so, it will be treated as "less than" the other one.
Otherwise, determine the chain nodes used one by one. If a node is greater, the chain will be greater; otherwise, they are same, 0 will be returned.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AnalysisResultExcluderExtensions
member.summary: Provides with extension methods on to check for excluders.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.AnalysisResultExcluderExtensions.SubtypeTextPattern
member.remarks:
Pattern:
(Row|Column)HiddenSingle\\d{3}
Options:
RegexOptions.Compiled
Explanation:
○ 1st capture group.
○ Match with 2 alternative expressions.
○ Match the string "Row".
○ Match the string "Column".
○ Match the string "HiddenSingle".
○ Match a Unicode digit exactly 3 times.

param.para: Indicates whether the constructor will automatically reverse the chain if the first node is greater than the last node, in order to make a good look.

member.summary: Indicates whether the current pattern is bound with a technique (i.e. having a technique name).
member.remarks: Due to design of this type, the derived types may not be consumed by showing a pattern. It may be a "segment" of a whole pattern (for example, a branch inside a multiple forcing chains). In such cases, this property will return , indicating there's no name corresponding to the pattern.

self-type-constraint.para: Indicates the type implementing this interface.

This type doesn't use any extra syntax to constraint such usage, but C# will check for it. The type will include a constraint that implements the interface itself to declare such "self constraint" usage: interface ISelfType<TSelf> where TSelf : ISelfType<TSelf> In addition, the type should be named TSelf in order to tell type parameters with the others.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.LinkComparison.Undirected
member.summary: Indicates the comparing rule is undirected, which means two instances will be compared, without any direction checking; i.e. node1 -> node2 is equal to node2 -> node1. This is the default option on comparing.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.LinkComparison.Directed
member.summary: Indicates the comparing rule is directed, which means two instances will be compared, with considerations on direction; i.e. node1 -> node2 is not equal to node2 -> node1.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.Node.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.remarks:
Format description:
Format character Description
m The map text. For example, r1c23(4)
S and s
The property value ( or ). If the character s is upper-cased, the result text will be upper-cased on initial letter.
For example, format value "m: S" will be replaced with value "r1c23(4): True".

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.StrongForcingChain.CompareTo(Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Components.StrongForcingChain)
member.summary: Determine which instance is greater.
member.param: The other instance to be compared.
member.remarks:
Order rule:
If is , is greater, return -1.
If is not , checks on length:
If length is not same, return 1 when is longer or -1 when is longer.
Determine whether one of two has "self constraint" (i.e. false -> true confliction).
If so, it will be treated as "less than" the other one.
Otherwise, determine the chain nodes used one by one. If a node is greater, the chain will be greater; otherwise, they are same, 0 will be returned.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Drivers.ChainingDriver
member.summary: Provides a driver that can generate normal chains and forcing chains.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Drivers.ChainingDriver.CollectChains(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Collect all chains and loops appeared in a grid.
member.param: Indicates whether this method allows for advanced links.
Indicates whether the method only find one valid step.
member.remarks:
Developer Notes
A valid chain can only be categorized by the following three cases:
Discontinuous Nice Loop
Start with weak link, alternating strong and weak links and return to itself of a weak link (with an even number of nodes, odd number of links).
Discontinuous Nice Loop
Start with strong link, alternating strong and weak links and return to itself of a strong link (with an even number of nodes, even number of links).
Continuous Nice Loop
Start with strong link, alternating strong and weak links and return to itself of a weak link (with an even number of nodes, even number of links).

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Patterns.AlmostLockedSetPattern
member.summary: Defines a data pattern that describes an ALS.
member.param: Indicates the mask of digits used.
Gets the possible cells that can store eliminations for the ALS.
The cells that can be eliminated, grouped by digit. The former 9 elements of the array is the cells that can be eliminated for the corresponding digit, and the last element is the merged cells.
member.remarks: An Almost Locked Set is a sudoku concept, which describes a case that n cells contains (n + 1) kinds of different digits. The special case is a bi-value cell.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Patterns.BorescoperDeadlyPatternPattern
member.summary:
Defines a pattern that is a Borescoper's Deadly Pattern technique pattern in theory. The sketch is like:
.-------.-------.-------. | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | P P . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . . | . . Q | S S . | | . . . | . . Q | S(S). | | . . . | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:
PThe first group of cells.
QThe second group of cells.
S
The square cells of size 3 or 4. The cell with the bracket (r8c8 in the picture) is optional.

param.name: mask
param.para: Indicates the internal mask.

This mask is of type , where the distribution of each bit is as follows:
0 7 14 21 28 35 42 49 56 ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ |-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------| ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ ↑ 0 8 16 24 32 40 48 56 64
where the bit [0..56] is for 8 cells, the last 7 bits determine the pattern is a heptagon or a octagon. If the value is 127 (not available), the pattern will be a heptagon.
Due to the drawing API, you have to check this file rather than the tip window.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Construction.Patterns.UniqueLoopPattern.IsValid``1(``0)
member.summary: Determine whether the specified loop is a valid unique loop or unique rectangle pattern.
member.typeparam: The type of the collection that can iterate on each instances.

remarks.para: This method uses a trick way (node-coloring) to check whether a loop is a unique loop. The parameter holds a list of cells, which are nodes of the loop. Then we begin to colorize each node with 2 different colors A and B. The only point we should notice is that the color between 2 adjacent nodes should be different (i.e. one is colored with A and the other should be colored with B). If at least one pair of cells in a same house are colored with a same color, it won't be a valid unique loop. Those colors stands for the final filling digits. Therefore, "Two cells in a same house are colored same" means "Two cells in a same house are filled with a same digit", which disobeys the basic sudoku rule.
This method won't check for whether the loop is a unique rectangle (of length 4). It means, a valid unique rectangle can also make this method return .

member.summary: Indicates the bottleneck is for a hardest step or a list of steps having a same hardest difficulty found in analyzer.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Primitives.BottleneckType.HardestLevel
member.summary: Indicates the bottleneck is for a step or a list of steps that hold the hardest difficulty level.

remarks.b: This field can only be used by checking a puzzle containing partial-marking and full-marking steps.

summary.para: Indicates the bottleneck for a step that makes the next step has a easier difficulty level than it.

For example, the first step is a chain (at "Fiendish" level), and the second step is a locked candidates (at "Moderate" level). In this case, the first step makes the second step to be easy, so it will be considered as a bottleneck under this rule.

remarks.b: This field can only be used by checking a puzzle containing partial-marking and full-marking steps.

summary.para: Indicates the bottleneck step is a step whose corresponding grid pattern only contains one step can makes such conclusion with it.

For example, the step is a hidden single. However, hidden single is the only step that the current grid can be found. If you don't apply it to puzzle, solving this puzzle cannot continue. Therefore, the step will be considered as a bottleneck under this rule.

remarks.b: This field can only be used by checking a puzzle only containing direct or partial-marking steps.
This field can only be used by checking a puzzle only containing direct and partial-marking steps.

self-type-constraint.para: Indicates the type implementing this interface.

This type doesn't use any extra syntax to constraint such usage, but C# will check for it. The type will include a constraint that implements the interface itself to declare such "self constraint" usage: interface ISelfType<TSelf> where TSelf : ISelfType<TSelf> In addition, the type should be named TSelf in order to tell type parameters with the others.

feature.name: static-dim
feature.para:
The keyword combinations , and are basic of DIM (default interface implementation) for members, introduced from C# 11.
Keyword combination Meaning
Such members must be implemented by concrete types (, , etc.).
Such members has a default implementation, no matter whether the member is re-implemented (same meaning with "overridding" for instance members in types, but is version) in concrete types, no compiler errors will be produced. If such members don't have an overridden one, default implementation will be invoked; otherwise, overridden one will be invoked.
Such members cannot be re-implemented. Default implmentation will be frozen and no way to override it.
Please note that the rule can only be used inside a .

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Step.CompareTo(Sudoku.Analytics.Step)
member.summary: Compares two instances, determining which one is greater.
member.param: The other object to be compared.
member.returns:
An value indicating the result. The comparison rule is:
If the argument is , return -1.
If the argument isn't , compare the technique used. If the code is greater, the instance will be greater.
The rule (2) can also be replaced with customized logic if you want to make the comparison perform better and more strict.

remarks.para: Please note that the argument can be , which is expected. If the argument is not of the same type as , we should return 1 to describe the comparison is not successful (the number 1 indicates is greater).
In addition, the return value must be -1, 0 or 1; otherwise, an unexpected behavior might be raised.

member.summary: Try to fetch the name of this technique step, with the specified culture.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Step.ToSimpleString(System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Gets the string representation for the current step, describing only its technique name and conclusions.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Step.NameCompareTo(Sudoku.Analytics.Step,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Compares the real name of the step to the specified one. This method is to distinct names on displaying in UI.
member.param: The other instance to be compared.
member.returns: An value indicating which one is logically larger.

remarks.para: Some techniques may not contain a correct order of comparison on its name. For example, in Chinese, digit characters 2 (i.e. "二") and 3 (i.e. "三") won't satisfy the comparison rule on the default order of their own Unicode value. 2 is for U + 4e8c, while 3 is for U + 4e09. In logic, U + 4e8c (2) has a larger Unicode value with 4e09 (3). However, in meaning of such text, 3 is greater than 2. This method will handle on this case.
By default, this method only checks for the Unicode order of two strings (default string comparison rule).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepAnalysisContext.MappingRelations
member.summary: Indicates the mapping relations. The index of the array means the base digit, and the target value at the specified index means the other mapping digit. If a value does not contain a mapping digit, the indexed value (target value) will be an empty array.

b.para: By default, the value is an empty array or trash memory value (stack-only structures can be used as locals, uninitialized). Due to being uninitialized, we should use this property very carefully.
Please firstly check for property . If that property returns an array not empty, you can use this property with safety.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.DeathBlossomStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Death Blossom step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Death Blossom
Death Blossom (House Blooming)
Death Blossom (Rectangle Blooming)
Death Blossom (A^nLS Blooming)

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.DeathBlossomStepSearcher.SearchExtendedTypes
member.summary: Indicates whether the step searcher searches for extended types.

remarks.para: This searcher uses a trick that starts with eliminations. From the solution, we can learn which candidates can be removed from the grid in fact.

Just suppose one of them is correct, and this case will lead to a confliction if some ALSes related to that supposed digit can lead to a same cell to be null (i.e. no digits can be filled). Therefore, we can remove the supposed digit from the containing cell.
This algorithm just makes the calculation simplified, in order to avoid complex searching on ALSes and a same-deletion leading.

member.summary: Create a instance and add it into the accumulator.
Create a instance and add it into the accumulator.
Search for A^nLS blooming type, and create a instance and add it into the accumulator if worth.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Unique Rectangle step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Basic types:
Unique Rectangle Type 1-6, Hidden Unique Rectangle
Avoidable Rectangle Type 1-3, 5, Hidden Avoidable Rectangle
Other types:
Unique Rectangle + Conjugate Pair (also called "Unique Rectangle + Strong Link")
Avoidable Rectangle + Hidden Single
Unique Rectangle + Baba Grouping
Unique Rectangle + ALS-XZ
Avoidable Rectangle + ALS-XZ
Unique Rectangle + Sue de Coq
Avoidable Rectangle + Sue de Coq
Unique Rectangle + XY-Wing, XYZ-Wing, WXYZ-Wing and W-Wing
Avoidable Rectangle + XY-Wing, XYZ-Wing, WXYZ-Wing and W-Wing
Unique/Avoidable Rectangle + Guardian (This program call it "External Types"):
Unique Rectangle External Type 1-4
Unique Rectangle External XY-Wing
Unique Rectangle External W-Wing
Unique Rectangle External ALS-XZ
Unique Rectangle External Turbot Fish
Unique Rectangle burred types:
Unique Rectangle Burred Subset
Miscellaneous:
Unique Rectangle 2D, 3X
Avoidable Rectangle 2D, 3X

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher.AllowIncompleteUniqueRectangles
member.summary: Indicates whether the UR can be incomplete. In other words, some of UR candidates can be removed before the pattern forms.
member.remarks:
For example, the complete pattern is:
ab | ab ab | ab
This is a complete pattern, and we may remove an ab in a certain corner. The incomplete pattern may not contain all four abs in the pattern.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher.SearchForExtendedUniqueRectangles
member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher can search for extended URs.
member.remarks: The basic types are type 1 to type 6, all other types are extended ones.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher.GetHighlightCells(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Get all highlight cells.
Check type 1.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ cornerCell (abc) ab ab ab

member.summary: Check type 2.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ corner1, corner2 (abc) (abc) ab ab

member.summary: Check type 3.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ corner1, corner2 (ab ) (ab ) abx aby

member.summary: Check type 4.
member.param: The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ corner1, corner2 (ab ) ab abx aby

member.summary: Check type 5.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ cornerCell (ab ) abc abc abc

member.summary: Check type 6.
member.param: The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ corner1 (ab ) aby abx (ab) ↑corner2

member.summary: Check hidden UR.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ cornerCell (ab ) abx aby abz

member.summary: Check UR + 2B/1SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ corner1, corner2 (ab ) (ab ) | | a | abx aby

member.summary: Check UR + 2D/1SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ corner1 (ab ) aby | | a | abx (ab ) ↑ corner2

member.summary: Check UR + 3x/1SL and UR + 3X/1SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

remarks.para:
The pattern:
↓ cornerCell (ab ) | abX | | | |a | | abz | abY a/bz
Suppose cell abX is filled with digit b, then a deadly pattern will be formed:
a | b b | a z
The pattern is called UR + 3x/1SL.
The pattern can be extended with cell a/bz to a pair of cells a/bS, and cell abz extends to abS, which will become UR + 3X/1SL (where S is a subset of digits).

member.summary: Check UR + 3X/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ cornerCell (ab ) abx | | b a | aby-----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3N/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ cornerCell (ab )-----abx a | | b | aby abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3U/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ cornerCell (ab )-----abx a
b aby -----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3E/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ cornerCell (ab )-----abx a
a aby -----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 4x/1SL and UR + 4X/1SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

member.summary: Check UR + 4x/2SL and UR + 4X/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

remarks.para:
The pattern:
corner1 corner2 ↓ a ↓ (abZ)--|--(abX) | | | |a | | abz | abY a/bz
Suppose cell abX is filled with digit b, then a deadly pattern will be formed:
a | b b | a z
The pattern is called UR + 4x/2SL.
The pattern can be extended with cell a/bz to a pair of cells a/bS, and cell abz extends to abS, which will become UR + 4X/2SL (where S is a subset of digits).

member.summary: Check UR + 4X/3SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
↓ corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) a | | b a | abz ----- abw

member.summary: Check UR + 4C/3SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
↓ corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) a | | a b | abz ----- abw

Subtype 2:
↓ corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) | a | | b | a | | abz abw

member.summary: Check burred subset.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

remarks.para:
The pattern:
↓ corner1, corner2 (abx) | (abcd) acd acd ab | ab
will remove the digit a in the corner cell abx.
The letter x may present multiple digits and not be used. However, if all digits x are false, the UR pattern will be degenerated into type 1, and the normal subset with digits c and d will be formed.

member.summary: Check UR-XY-Wing, UR-XYZ-Wing, UR-WXYZ-Wing and AR-XY-Wing, AR-XYZ-Wing and AR-WXYZ-Wing.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
Indicates whether the corner cells cannot see each other.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
↓ corner1 (ab ) abxy yz xz (ab ) abxy * ↑ corner2
Note that the pair of cells abxy should be in the same house.

Subtype 2:
↓ corner1 (ab ) abx xz aby (ab ) * yz ↑ corner2

member.summary: Check UR + SdC.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
| xyz ab+ ab+ | abxyz abxyz | xyz ----------+------------ (ab)(ab) | ↑ corner1, corner2

member.summary: Check UR + ALS and AR + ALS.
member.param: Indicates whether the method searches for avoidable rectangles.

param.name: alses
param.para: The ALS patterns found.

para.para: The keyword means the argument and local variable can only be used inside the method. This means you cannot use this variable and argument outside the scope, such as new RefStructType(scoped_variable), return scoped_variable and field = scoped_variable. Such expressions may store the variables, unsafely expanding the variable's lifecycle.

param.para: This parameter expects a keyword because may assign to because expects a instance, which is a very "implicit" compiler error that we cannot aware of this at once.
By appending modifier , compiler will know that this parameter should only be used inside this method or other places allowing such usages (recursive usages), which won't extend its lifecycle.
Such usage is same as method .
Please check this page to learn more information on CS8350.

remarks.para:
The pattern:
↓ cell1, cells2 ab | abc * ab | abcd * | cdef ----+------------ | def | def
where a cell cdef and 2 cells def will be formed an ALS pattern. Therefore, a chain is formed: abcd(d) == {abc, abcd}(c) -- cdef(c) == {def, def}(d) => * != d
In addition, this pattern will cover all possible cases of UR + 2D and UR + 3X.

member.summary: Check AR + Hidden single.
member.param: The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

remarks.para: The pattern:

↓corner1 a | aby. . abx | a . b | . . . ↑corner2(cell 'a')
There's only one cell can be filled with the digit 'b' besides the cell 'aby'.

summary.para: Check UR/AR + Guardian (i.e. UR External Type 2) and UR External Type 1.
A UR external type 1 is a special case for type 2, which means only one guardian cell will be used.

member.summary: Check UR/AR + Guardian, with external subset (i.e. UR External Type 3).
Check UR/AR + Guardian, with external conjugate pair (i.e. UR External Type 4).

member.summary: Check UR + Guardian, with external turbot fish.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher.CheckExternalWWing(System.Collections.Generic.SortedSet{Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.UniqueRectangleStep},Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,Sudoku.Analytics.StepAnalysisContext@,System.Int32[],System.Int16,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Check UR + Guardian, with external W-Wing.
Check UR/AR + Guardian, with external XY-Wing.
Check UR/AR + Guardian, with external ALS-XZ rule.
Check UR-W-Wing and AR-W-Wing.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
↓ corner1 xz abx (ab ) (ab ) aby yz ↑ corner2

Subtype 2:
↓ corner1 xz (ab ) abx abx (ab ) xz ↑ corner2
Please note that corner cells may be aligned as a same row or column.

para.i: Also, this method is useless because it may be replaced with another techniques such as UR-XY-Wing and UR External Type 2.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.ExocetStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with an Exocet step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Junior Exocet
Weak Exocet
Lame Weak Exocet
Double Exocet
Senior Exocet
Complex Junior Exocet
Complex Senior Exocet
Advanced Complex Junior Exocet
Advanced Complex Senior Exocet
The core method to check for Junior Exocet sub-types.
member.param: The analysis context to be used for accumulate steps.
The grid as the candidate referencing object.
The cells of the target. The target cell only contains empty cells; non-empty ones will be ignored.
The grouped cells for the argument , by is containing crossline house.
The cells of cross-line. The cross-line cells contain 18 cells regardless of its state: empty or non-empty.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.AlmostLockedCandidatesStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with an Almost Locked Candidates step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Basic types:
Almost Locked Pair
Almost Locked Triple
Extended types (contains value cells):
Extended Almost Locked Triple
Extended Almost Locked Quadruple

member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher checks the almost locked quadruple.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.AlmostLockedCandidatesStepSearcher.CheckValueTypes
member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher checks for value types.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.AlmostLockedCandidatesStepSearcher.Collect(Sudoku.Analytics.StepAnalysisContext@,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,System.Boolean)
member.param: Indicates whether the method checks for value cells.

remarks.para:
The diagrams:
ALP: abx aby | ab abz |
ALT: abcw abcx | abc abc abcy abcz |
Algorithm:

If the cell ab (in ALP) or abc (in ALT) is filled with the digit p, then the cells abx and aby (in ALP) and abcw and abcx (in ALT) can't fill the digit p. Therefore the digit p can only be filled into the left-side block.
If the block only contains those cells that can contain the digit p, the ALP or ALT will be formed, and the elimination is z (in ALP) and y and z (in ALT).

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.LockedCandidatesStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Locked Candidates step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Pointing
Claiming

remarks.para:
The main idea of this searching operation:
.-------.-------.-------. | C C C | A A A | A A A | | B B B | . . . | . . . | | B B B | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
For example, if the cells C form a locked candidates, there'll be two cases:
Pointing (Type 1): Cells A contains the digit, but cells B doesn't.
Claiming (Type 2): Cells B contains the digit, but cells A doesn't.
Therefore, the algorithm is:

Use . |(, ) to merge digits mask from cells A, cells B and cells C, and suppose the notation a is the mask result for cells A, b is the mask result for cells B, and c is the mask result for cells C. If the equation (c & (a ^ b)) != 0 is correct, the locked candidates exists, and the result of the expression c & (a ^ b) is a mask that holds the digits of the locked candidates.

Why this expression? a ^ b means the digit can only appear in either cells A or cells B. If both or neither, the digit won't contain the locked candidates pattern. Because of the optimization of the performance, we use the predefined table to iterate on all possible location where may form a locked candidates.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.SingleStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Single step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Common techniques:
Full House (If the property is )
Last Digit (If the property is )
Naked Single
Direct techniques:
Crosshatching
Indirect techniques:
Hidden Single

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.SingleStepSearcher.CheckForHiddenSingleAndLastDigit(Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.SingleStepSearcher,Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,Sudoku.Analytics.StepAnalysisContext@,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Checks for existence of hidden single and last digit conclusion in the specified house.
member.returns: Not if conclusion can be found.

remarks.para: The main idea of hidden single is to search for a digit can only appear once in a house, so we should check all possibilities in a house to found whether the house exists a digit that only appears once indeed.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.StepSearcherAttribute
member.summary: Indicates a type marked this attribute is a runnable .
member.param: Indicates the key in resource dictionary.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.StepSearcherAttribute.#ctor(System.String,Sudoku.Categorization.Technique[])
member.summary: Indicates a type marked this attribute is a runnable .
member.param: Indicates the key in resource dictionary.

summary.para: Indicates the technique searcher doesn't use any cached fields in implementation, i.e. caching-free or caching-safe.
This property can be used by checking free-caching rules, in order to inline-declaring data members, storing inside another step searcher type, or creating a temporary logic to call this searcher.
Indicates the technique searcher always uses cached fields in implementation, i.e. caching-unsafe.
As a property reversed from , this property tags for a step searcher not using . If a step searcher type always use caching fields without any doubt, this property should be set with .

para.i: This property won't be used in API, but it may be used in future versions.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.UniqueRectangleStep
member.summary: Provides with a step that is a Unique Rectangle technique.
member.param: Indicates the second digit used. This value is always greater than .
Indicates the cells used in this pattern.
Indicates whether the current rectangle is an avoidable rectangle. If , an avoidable rectangle; otherwise, a unique rectangle.

param.name: absoluteOffset
param.para: Indicates the absolute offset.

The value is an value, as an index, in order to distinct with all unique rectangle patterns. The greater the value is, the later the corresponding pattern will be processed. The value must be between 0 and 485, because the total number of possible patterns is 486.

member.summary: Provides with a step that is an Exocet technique.
member.param: Indicates the mask that holds a list of digits used in the pattern.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.ExocetStep.#ctor(System.ReadOnlyMemory{Sudoku.Concepts.Conclusion},Sudoku.Drawing.View[],Sudoku.Analytics.Configuration.StepGathererOptions,System.Int16,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@)
member.summary: Provides with a step that is an Exocet technique.
member.param: Indicates the mask that holds a list of digits used in the pattern.

summary.para: Indicates the delta value of the pattern.

The values can be -2, -1, 0, 1 and 2, separated with 3 groups:
Value Description
-2 or -1 (< 0) The base contain more cells than the target, meaning the pattern will be a "Senior Exocet"
1 or 2 (> 0)
The target contain more cells than the base, meaning the pattern will contain extra items like conjugate pairs of other digits
0 The base has same number of cells with the target, a standard "Junior Exocet" will be formed

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.ComplexFishStep
member.summary: Provides with a step that is a Complex Fish technique.
member.param: Indicates the fins, positioned outside the fish. They will be defined if cover sets cannot be fully covered, with the number of cover sets being equal to the number of base sets.
Indicates the fins, positioned inside the fish. Generally speaking, they will be defined if they are in multiple base sets.
Indicates whether the fish is a Franken fish. If , a Franken fish; otherwise, a Mutant fish.
Indicates whether the fish contains any cannibalism.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.FishStep
member.summary: Provides with a step that is a Fish technique.
member.param: Indicates the mask that contains the base sets.
Indicates the mask that contains the cover sets.

param.name: isSashimi
param.para: Indicates whether the fish is a Sashimi fish.

All cases are as below:
The fish is a sashimi finned fish.
The fish is a normal finned fish.
The fish doesn't contain any fin.

member.param: Indicates whether the pattern is a Siamese Fish.

member.param: Indicates whether the pattern is a Siamese Fish.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.FishStep.Size
member.remarks:
The name of the corresponding names are:
2X-Wing
3Swordfish
4Jellyfish
5Squirmbag (or Starfish)
6Whale
7Leviathan
Other fishes of sizes not appearing in above don't have well-known names.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.ComplexSingleStep
member.summary: Represents a data structure that describes for a technique of Complex Single.
member.param: Indicates the single technique that is based on.

param.name: indirectTechniques
param.para: Indicates the indirect techniques used in this pattern.

This value is an array of array of instances, describing the detail usage on the complex combination of indirect technique usages. For example:
Value Meaning
[[, ]] The naked single will use a pointing and a claiming technique in one step
[[], []] We should apply a pointing firstly, and then claiming appears, then naked single appears

3 XY-Wing or XYZ-Wing
4 WXYZ-Wing
5 VWXYZ-Wing
6 UVWXYZ-Wing
7 TUVWXYZ-Wing
8 STUVWXYZ-Wing
9 RSTUVWXYZ-Wing

member.summary: Represents a step of type , presenting the third subtype.

self-type-constraint.para: Indicates the type implementing this interface.

This type doesn't use any extra syntax to constraint such usage, but C# will check for it. The type will include a constraint that implements the interface itself to declare such "self constraint" usage: interface ISelfType<TSelf> where TSelf : ISelfType<TSelf> In addition, the type should be named TSelf in order to tell type parameters with the others.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Behaviors.Ittoryu.GridIttoryuExtensions.IsIttoryu(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,System.Nullable{Sudoku.Behaviors.Ittoryu.DisorderedIttoryuDigitPath}@)
member.summary: Determine whether the specified grid is an ittoryu puzzle, meaning the puzzle can be finished via digits one by one.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Behaviors.Ittoryu.GridIttoryuExtensions.IsIttoryu(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,Sudoku.Categorization.TechniqueSet,System.Nullable{Sudoku.Behaviors.Ittoryu.DisorderedIttoryuDigitPath}@)
member.summary: Determine whether the specified grid is an ittoryu puzzle, meaning the puzzle can be finished via digits one by one, with checking using the specified techniques.

param.name: techniques
param.para: The techniques supported.

The value is a instance. You can only chose one or more fields in the following list:
(Full House)
(Hidden Single in Block)
(Hidden Single in Row)
(Hidden Single in Column)
(Naked Single)
For example, [Technique.FullHouse, Technique.NakedSingle] is valid argument, but [Technique.NakedPair] is not.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Categorization.SingleSubtypeExtensions
member.summary: Provides with extension methods on .

member.name: M:Sudoku.Categorization.SingleSubtypeExtensions.IsUnnecessary(Sudoku.Categorization.SingleSubtype)
member.summary: Indicates whether the specified subtype is unnecessary in practice. For example, a naked single with 8 digits in a block will form a full house, which is unnecessary.
member.returns: A result indicating whether the subtype is unnecessary.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Categorization.SingleSubtypeExtensions.IsAlgorithmUnnecessary(Sudoku.Categorization.SingleSubtype)
member.summary: Indicates whether the specified subtype is unnecessary in solving algorithm, but it can be appeared in a solving step produced by a user.
member.returns: A result indicating whether the subtype is unnecessary.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Categorization.SingleSubtypeExtensions.GetExcludersCount(Sudoku.Categorization.SingleSubtype)
member.summary: Try to get the number of excluders that the current single subtype will use. This method will return a non-zero value if and only if it is a hidden single.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Categorization.SingleSubtypeExtensions.GetExcludersCount(Sudoku.Categorization.SingleSubtype,Sudoku.Concepts.HouseType)
member.summary: Try to get the number of excluders that the current single subtype will use in the specified house type.

member.summary:
Try to get related field that corresponds the current subtype. All values are:
(if is )

param.name: subtleValue
param.para: A indicating whether the return value should subtle the handling on return field. If the value is , hidden singles will be split into block, row and column subtypes, instead of returning a unified value .
The return value is .

member.exception: Throws when the argument is out of range.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Categorization.TechniqueExtensions.IsAssignment(Sudoku.Categorization.Technique)
member.summary: Determine whether the specified technique produces assignments.

remarks.para: In mechanism, an assignment technique must produce assignment conclusions. However, some techniques can also produce them like BUG + 1, Discontinuous Nice Loop, etc.. This method today won't return for such techniques now, but this rule might be changed in the future.
If you want to check whether the technique is a single, please call method or instead.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Categorization.TechniqueExtensions.IsSingle(Sudoku.Categorization.Technique)
member.summary: Determine whether the specified technique is a single technique.

member.summary: Determine whether the specified technique is a technique that can only be produced in direct views.

member.summary: Combine the technique with indirect technique, to produce a new field, describing the complex single usage. For example, combining with will produce .
member.param: The direct technique used. The value can be:
The indirect technique used. The value can be ones of group and .
member.exception: Throws when the argument is not a direct technique.

var techniques = TechniqueSets.All; var another = techniques[..]; // Copy all elements.

feature.name: scoped-keyword
feature.para: The keyword means the argument and local variable can only be used inside the method. This means you cannot use this variable and argument outside the scope, such as new RefStructType(scoped_variable), return scoped_variable and field = scoped_variable. Such expressions may store the variables, unsafely expanding the variable's lifecycle.

summary.para: Provides with the type that contains a module initializer method, called automatically by the CLR (Common Language Runtime) to initialize some values.

para.i: The type is called by the compiler and the CLR (Common Language Runtime), which means you cannot use any members in this type manually.

target.name: method
target.summary: Called by the runtime automatically while booting on this solution to initialize the values, data members or any other things that can or should be initialized here.
target.remarks: The concept module is different with assembly. The solution can contain multiple assemblies, while each assembly can contain multiple modules. However, due to the design of Visual Studio project file system, each assembly will only contain one module by default.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Resources.AnalyticsResources.SettingsPage_GridSizeDescription
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Changes with the size of the grid displayed in most of pages, in pixels. However, this option doesn't change some sudoku panes displayed in modal windows (a kind of window that is suddenly appears when the program wants to tell you some messages which are usually warnings or errors). Min value is 360, max value is 800, and default value is 610..

feature.name: scoped-keyword
feature.para: The keyword means the argument and local variable can only be used inside the method. This means you cannot use this variable and argument outside the scope, such as new RefStructType(scoped_variable), return scoped_variable and field = scoped_variable. Such expressions may store the variables, unsafely expanding the variable's lifecycle.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Runtime.InteropServices.Hodoku.HodokuCompatibility.GetHodokuLibraryPrefix(Sudoku.Categorization.Technique)
member.summary: Try to get the prefix of the specified technique. The return value will be a four-digit value represented as a value. For more information please visit this link.

returns.para: A value using a four-digit value to describe a technique used in a sudoku grid, which is defined by the project HoDoKu.
If this technique is not supported by HoDoKu, will be returned.

remarks.para: Please note that some technique fields are separated into multiple sub-types, but they all belong to a same type of a technique supported by HoDoKu. For example, and are supported by HoDoKu as one technique "Sue de Coq", so if you get the prefix from the two fields, the return value are same (i.e. the value "1101").

member.exception: Throws when the specified value is not defined by the type , or the value is .

member.name: M:Sudoku.Runtime.InteropServices.Hodoku.HodokuCompatibility.GetAliases(Sudoku.Categorization.Technique)
member.summary: Gets all possible aliased names that are defined by HoDoKu.
member.returns: The array of aliased names, or if it is not defined by HoDoKu.
member.exception: Throws when the specified value is not defined by the type , or the value is .

summary.para: Interceptors are an experimental compiler feature planned to ship in .NET 8 (with support for C# only). The feature may be subject to breaking changes or removal in a future release.

An interceptor is a method which can declaratively substitute a call to an interceptable method with a call to itself at compile time. This substitution occurs by having the interceptor declare the source locations of the calls that it intercepts. This provides a limited facility to change the semantics of existing code by adding new code to a compilation (e.g. in a source generator).
